title: LILAIA
content:
LILAIA (Lilaea) was the Naiad-nymph of the spring, well or fountain of the town of Lilaia in Phokis (central
        Greece). She was a daughter of the local river-god Kephisos (Cephisus).

Lilaia was probably identified with Liriope, wife of Kephisos.

LILAEA (Lilaia), a Naiad, a daughter of Cephissus, from whom the town of Lilaea in Phocis was believed to have
        derived its name. (Paus. x. 33. & 2.)

Source: Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology.

Homeric Hymn 3 to Pythian Apollo 239 ff (trans. Evelyn-White) (Greek epic C7th or 6th
          B.C.) :
        "Kephisos' (Cephisus') sweet stream which pours forth its sweet-flowing water from Lilaia (Lilaea)."

Pausanias, Description of Greece 10. 32. 4 (trans. Jones) (Greek travelogue C2nd
          A.D.) :
        "They say that Lilaia (Lilaea) was one of the Naiades, as they are called, a daughter of the Kephisos
        (Cephisus), and that after this Nymphe the city [of Liliai in Phokis] was named."
